bibl.title: Letter from C.C. Williamson to Henry Rose Carter, June 27, 1922

div1.p: Williamson requests that Carter review a manuscript on the yellow fever campaign in Ecuador. He suggests it may be useful for Carter's planned publication on the history of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from C.C. Williamson to Henry Rose Carter, June 27, 1922
div1.opener:
GEORGE E. VINCENT, PRESIDENT
EDWIN R. EMBREE, SECRETARY
JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER, JR.
CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES
L. G. MYERS, TREASURER
ROBERT H. KIRK, COMPTROLLER
THE ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION
61 BROADWAY, NEW YORK
MEMBERS
JOHN G. AGAR
WALLACE BUTTRICK
JOHN W. DAVIS
SIMON FLEXNER
RAYMOND B. FOSDICK
FREDERICK T. GATES
VERNON KELLOGG
HARRY FRATT JUDEON
JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER
JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER, JR.
WICKLIFFE ROSE
JULIUS ROSENWALD
MARTIN A. MYERSON
FREDERICK STRAUSS
GEORGE E. VINCENT
June 27, 1922
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
At Doctor Russell's suggestion I am sending you a manuscript
which represents an effort to tell the story of the yellow fever campaign
in Ecuador as completely as our records make it possible, and in a fairly
readable form. This was undertaken at Doctor Connor's special request.
Although he had published two or three articles on the work in Guayaquil,
and much has been said about it in our regular reports, he felt that there
was still lacking a complete authoritative account.

We ordinarily would think of having such a report published in
some medical journal. This, however, seems too long, and Doctor Russell
thinks it is written in too popular a way for a scientific journal. Sim-
ilar reports we have, at times, lithographed. This process would repro-
duce the typewritten page in any number of copies desired, at a moderate
expense. We hesitate, however, to follow this method in the Peru report,
because it does not effectively get it on record with the scientific world
and libraries.

Doctor Russell thinks that perhaps you could make considerable
use of it in your chapter on Peru. Although the manuscript does not in-
dicate it, we would expect to publish it as a report by Doctor Connor,
and in connection with any use that is made of it credit should be given
to Doctor Connor.

We are not at all sure that this suggestion would meet with
Doctor Connor's approval. Will you please look over the manuscript and
let us know whether you could use it and to what extent. If you do find
it adapted to your purpose, we will then consult Doctor Connor and hope
that he will approve Doctor Russell's suggestion.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, C C Williamson
Director of Information Service Doctor Henry R. Carter,
2121 California Street, N.W.,
Washington, D. C.
